channel.title: Scientists extract images directly from brain
channel.description:
Source: http://digg.com/general_sciences/Scientists_extract_images_directly_from_brain
Japan’s ATR Computational Neuroscience Laboratories have developed new brain analysis technology that can reconstruct the images inside a person ’s mind and display them on a computer monitor, it was announced on December 11. Further development of the technology may soon make it possible to view other people’s dreams while they sleep.
Imagine the endless possibilities of this, like dream recording and other things.

item.title: Scientists extract images directly from brain
item.dc:creator: @Rictoo Rictoo
item.description:
@Rictoo wrote:

Yeah, it would be really interesting to see how that would work. Since like, you don’t exactly remember your dreams as a concrete state of events. Seeing it all in a straight line on a monitor would be interesting, if not fucking bizarre.

Read full topic
item.source: Scientists extract images directly from brain

item.title: Scientists extract images directly from brain
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

Rictoo, but then how would it work on dreams? I’m not talking about it at it’s current state, they said it could be applied to dreams some day so surely it could do drug trips too?

Read full topic
item.source: Scientists extract images directly from brain

item.title: Scientists extract images directly from brain
item.dc:creator: @Rictoo Rictoo
item.description:
@Rictoo wrote:

[quote=“jme, post:10, topic:251401”][quote author=sanga282 link=topic=331827.msg2591312#msg2591312 date=1229779913]

Source: http://digg.com/general_sciences/Scientists_extract_images_directly_from_brain

Japan’s ATR Computational Neuroscience Laboratories have developed new brain analysis technology that can reconstruct the images inside a person ’s mind and display them on a computer monitor, it was announced on December 11. Further development of the technology may soon make it possible to view other people’s dreams while they sleep.

Imagine the endless possibilities of this, like dream recording and other things.

Personally I don’t believe it, or it isn’t nearly as cool as it sounds. I still have to read the article though.

For dreams, I think drug trips would be a lot more interesting but also I think impossible. Probably not too many people here have experienced this, but I’ve been multiple different places/worlds/realities simultaneously. I’d like to see that machine capture that.

thats easy we just set alight some weed and shiz around the CPU, then its as capable as you If that fails ram some LSD in the USB slot
[/quote]

No, give it to me.

But anyways this thing is only black and white at the moment. I still don’t think it could ever capture anything proper from a salvia trip or something though.[/quote]

You’re confusing mental state with the visual cortex. This machine would replicate exactly what is going through your visual cortex, ignoring your entire mental state of “being multiple realities” or whatever.

Read full topic

item.title: Scientists extract images directly from brain
item.dc:creator: @Ske Ske
item.description:
@Ske wrote:

I really dont understand what you’re trying to say but i’m sure it could work
For example, when the person is asleep, you use the machine to capture the dreams.
And to test if it was his real dream, you question the person and later on you show the images that were captured.
Then you compare.

Read full topic
item.source: Scientists extract images directly from brain

item.title: Scientists extract images directly from brain
item.dc:creator: @Squigglyo Squigglyo
item.description:
@Squigglyo wrote:

the concept is awesome…

but the image that comes up, you will either recognise right away and be like ‘omg i remember that!!! the machine works!!!’ or you wont recognize it at all, and the scientists will be like ‘omg, it must be from your subconscious!!! our machine works!!!’

so, this machine will produce images that cant possibly be considered fact. Even if it can bring pictures from your mind 1005 correctly, your mind can create images based on your perseption of what you think the event is… so using it on criminals to get ‘confessions’ will just prove that they can comprehend what the crime actualy was, and could have just created the event in there head using imagination.

Great idea… but useless.

Read full topic
